description: Probably ultimately based on Old French Old French timon (“tiller”) + English guy.

entries.meaning: (nautical) A rope used on a ship to prevent other lines and riggings tangling with each other.
examples: But there is nothing so tedious as sitting by when two old shipmates are calling out, ‘Do you remember the three days’ blow in the Mona Passage? – Do you remember Wilkins and his timenoguy?’
